channel.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
channel.description:
[center][size=12pt][b]Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music[/b][/size] by Ron[/center]
Songs you download off the internet may be very risky. Some RIAA personel embed code into the music. We know how sometimes when people (not me) download music, they click on it, and it doesn't open, instead it opens a hole on your computer or opens a web page up saying "DON'T STEAL MUSIC!" lol.
BUT, the new thing now is to embed code in the file that would let the RIAA know that you're listening to an illegal download. It tries to connect to the internet, and when it does, your IP gets logged so hopefully you have a proxy. If you don't then you might just get screwed.
The way to cover your tracks is simple. Download [url=http://www.mp3do.com/soundrecorder.html]All Sound Recorder XP[/url] which is a pay program. Install it and run it. Go to Start > Programs > All Sound Recorder XP > All Sound Recorder XP. This will appear.
[img]http://img153.imageshack.us/img153/3691/allsound17pz.jpg[/img]
Click on the Create New Recording Work button. This window should show up.
[img]http://img233.imageshack.us/img233/5837/allsound28oa.jpg[/img]
Type in whatever file name you want in there. Now open up Windows Media Player or some other kind of music player and find the song you want to record. Now, very quickly, click on the Record Button [img]http://img54.imageshack.us/img54/8650/allsound34vc.jpg[/img] and then click on the song you want to record.
Once the song is finished, stop the recording. The file should be saved in the folder... C:\Program Files\All Sound Recorder XP\output\
Go to the folder, find your file, play it and see if it works! Compare it to the file you recorded and see if the file size is different. It only takes about an extra 100 KB (0.1 MB) to embed a good keylogger in a file.
Viola! You're finished! Now you have your own copy of an illegal song, but no one would ever know if you actually downloaded it. Congratulations.
~Ron
Edit: Updated a lot because I was in the middle fo finals before.

item.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
item.dc:creator: @deoxys505 deoxys505
item.description:
@deoxys505 wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:6, topic:3377”]Even with proxies, it might be a problem. Because news showed up on yahoo.com that the riaa has been starting to embed code into songs that leaves your computer wide open for attack and could be spraying out your personal information lol. Thats why I posted this tutorial. Rerecord your songs, and delete the old ones. That way you’re in the clear. ;)[/quote]if the spray your info on the web and stuff you could sue. if they are the only ones looking @ it, then its legal but if they publish it on the web or in books/magazines etc. then you can sue.

Read full topic

item.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Ron:

Yeah… If my computer ‘just fucked up’ then why didn’t my other songs screw up? The only songs that screwed up were the ones I ripped off my CDs that I bought. The ones I downloaded, did not get messed up, and to this day, they are still not messed up. The only songs that were messed up were the ones I bought.

Uhh, because the problem was in the ripping, not the playback?

Read full topic
item.source: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!

item.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

deltatsunami:

You do realize that the RIAA won’t go after every single individual and sue them? It will be too costly and it will not be a efficient way. They only go after people who are sharing $1000 worth of songs or more or a leaked copy of an eagerly waited album.

You do realize that the RIAA has been doing that since early 2000? Read www.zeropaid.com, every week or so they post more people who are getting sued for stealing music.

Mopman:

That has nothing to do with “RIAA code”. Your computer just fucked up.

Yeah… If my computer ‘just fucked up’ then why didn’t my other songs screw up? The only songs that screwed up were the ones I ripped off my CDs that I bought. The ones I downloaded, did not get messed up, and to this day, they are still not messed up. The only songs that were messed up were the ones I bought.

uncfan1119:

You should use the camtiasa audio editor . Record it then edit out the space of no sound.

Hmm, I might just try that. Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

rob1601:

I do not want to mention certain programs but many of them are doing a similar thing to this. They are all spying on your pc

Yep.

zoss0:

I like to use Audacity instead. Check it out, a nice free sound program that’s ok. http://audacity.sourceforge.net/

Cool software, but it can’t detect the software code. I just read the features. If it got strip our the software code that does all that goofy shit like make the RIAA spy, etc. Then it would be really sweet.

An example of goofy shit. I ripped tracks off CDs I bought about 8 months ago, and about 2 months ago, all the music I ripped off from CDs I bought were sped up like crazy! When I played the song, the song would play very very very very quickly. It sounded like the chipmunks lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Cover Tracks if you Download Illegal Music - UPDATED!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[quote=“tom55, post:85, topic:3377”][quote author=Ron link=topic=3993.msg111432#msg111432 date=1154401741]
The embedded code would be in the file itself.

So if you ran some kind of recorder while you played the song, only the song would be extracted.
[/quote]

What If I open the file and then copy all the waves. Then close the window, and open a new one and paste the waves and save it, Would this get rid of the embled code?[br][size=1]Posted at: August 04, 2006, 11:34:15 PM[/size][hr]… Ron[/quote]
I think, I’m not sure about that one. You’re trying to make a shortcut across it, but I’m not sure if that would do any good. It would be like opening up a text file, selecting all of it, creating a new text file, and pasting it. It would be the same, I think. I could be wrong though.

Read full topic
